item.title: This Is What Venezuelans Really Want
item.description: We have long faced a brutal paradox: an absent yet omnipotent state.
item.dc:creator: Colette Capriles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: How Trump Fixed On a Maduro Loyalist as Venezuela’s New Leader
item.description: Nicolás Maduro balked at a gilded exile. U.S. officials then saw a more pliant option in his vice president, Delcy Rodríguez, known for stabilizing Venezuela’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Tyler Pager, Simon Romero and Julie Turkewitz

media:content.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vice President Delcy Rodríguez of Venezuela, now the country’s interim leader, speaking at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 2019.

item.title: China’s Russian Town Has Log Cabins and Cyrillic Signs, but No Russians
item.description: Enhe was once home to thousands of ethnic Russians. Under Xi Jinping’s push for ethnic unity, little remains beyond nostalgia and props for tourists.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

media:content.media:description: Buildings with Russian-style decorative features aimed at attracting tourists in Ergun, China, in November.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Ranchers Are Burning the Prairie to Save It From the Trees
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 3, 2025.

item.title: $650,000 in Pop Star Memorabilia? These Superfans Know Few Limits.
item.description: For megafans of megastars like Madonna and Mariah Carey, obsessive collecting is an emotional, not a financial, investment. The tradition dates to ancient Rome.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

media:content.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: By surrounding himself in Madonna memorabilia, James Harknett said, he felt “comforted and excited.”

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 4, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 4, 2026.

item.title: Why Trump Removed Venezuela’s Maduro
item.description: David E. Sanger, our national security correspondent, describes the implications of President Trump’s launching of the attack that captured the Venezuelan president, and Trump’s declaration that the United States would “run the country.”
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Leila Medina and June Kim

item.title: Con Venezuela, Trump abre una nueva era de riesgo para EE. UU.
item.description: El presidente abrió un nuevo capítulo en la construcción nacional estadounidense al declarar que EE. UU. había derrocado al líder de Venezuela y que iba a “manejar” el país por un periodo indefinido.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Personas en Doral, Florida, celebrando la captura del presidente Nicolás Maduro por parte de las fuerzas estadounidenses el sábado.

item.title: Heavy Rain and King Tides Cause Flooding in California
item.description: Highways were blocked and a regional airport shut down on Saturday when the latest in a long run of drenching rainstorms coincided with especially high tides.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Ethan Swope/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Tidal flooding in low-lying areas of Marin County, in the San Francisco Bay Area, left Highway 101 awash and inundated neighborhoods surrounding Corte Madera Creek on Saturday.

item.title: ‘What Will Happen Tomorrow?’ Venezuelans Fear Chaos After U.S. Attack
item.description: Nicolás Maduro was deeply unpopular. But those who opposed him worry that U.S. intervention may reap further instability.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In Caracas, the streets were chillingly silent on Saturday, save for a few small demonstrations organized by the government to protest Nicolás Maduro’s ouster.

item.title: ¿EE. UU. puede ‘manejar’ legalmente Venezuela? Esto es lo que sabemos
item.description: El operativo reaviva la discusión sobre la legalidad de la intervención de 1989 en Panamá, aunado a la promesa del presidente Trump de “manejar” Venezuela y la situación formal de Nicolás Maduro como presidente.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Leonardo Fernandez Viloria/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Humo saliendo de Fuerte Tiuna, un complejo militar en Caracas, el sábado por la mañana. Tropas estadounidenses capturaron al presidente Nicolás Maduro en un asalto a un refugio de seguridad.

item.title: Maduro’s Final Plea: ‘No War. Yes Peace.’
item.description: Days before he was captured, Nicolás Maduro expounded on his precarious position — and tried to offer an olive branch to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nicolás Maduro at a rally in Caracas last month.

item.title: Al menos 40 personas murieron en el ataque de EE. UU., según un funcionario venezolano
item.description: Aseguró que entre los muertos había civiles y militares. Al menos una de las bajas civiles fue en un ataque aéreo estadounidense en las afueras de Caracas, según su familia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Wilman González lleva los muebles que consiguió salvar de su casa en Catia La Mar, Venezuela, después de que volaran por los aires durante los ataques aéreos. Su tía, Rosa González, de 80 años, que vivía con él, murió durante el ataque.

item.title: Maduro’s Capture Prompts Protests and Celebrations in U.S. Cities
item.description: Opponents of the U.S. intervention in Venezuela called it illegal. Supporters celebrated the ouster of Nicolás Maduro, the country’s authoritarian president.
item.dc:creator: Robert Chiarito, Adam Sella and Raúl Vilchis

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators marching toward the Trump Tower in Chicago on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuelan Asylum Seekers Worry About What Comes Next
item.description: For many, the removal of the Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro has not eased uncertainty about their immigration status in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Venezuelans and Venezuelan Americans celebrating in Doral, Fla. on Saturday.

item.title: Por qué llamé al presidente Trump a las 4:30 a. m.
item.description: ¿Cómo pudo un periodista del Times ponerse en contacto con el presidente justo después de que este anunció la captura del líder de Venezuela?
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump habla en una rueda de prensa en Mar-a-Lago, Palm Beach, Florida, el sábado.

item.title: In Wake of U.S. Strike, Venezuelan Paramilitaries Are Little Seen
item.description: As the armed civilian groups often used to suppress protests kept a low profile, the role they might play in the country’s new situation remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: Matias Delacroix/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Armed civilians in La Guaira, Venezuela, after the U.S. strikes in the country on Saturday. The groups known as colectivos, whose function is often to suppress protesters, stayed mostly out of sight on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Indictment of Maduro Cites Cocaine Smuggling, Trade in Which Venezuela’s Role Is Believed to Be Modest
item.description: Experts have said that Venezuela is not a major drug producer but rather a minor cocaine transit country, with most of the cocaine flowing through it headed to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Annie Correal

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nicolás Maduro making a speech in Caracas last year.

item.title: Trump Plunges the U.S. Into a New Era of Risk in Venezuela
item.description: President Trump opened a new chapter in American nation building as he declared that the United States had toppled Venezuela’s leader and would “run” the country for an indefinite period.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: People in Doral, Fla., celebrating the capture of President Nicolás Maduro by U.S. forces on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuelan Official Says at Least 40 People Were Killed in U.S. Attack
item.description: The official said the dead included civilians and military personnel. At least one of the civilians was killed in a U.S. airstrike outside of Caracas, according to her family.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Wilman Gonzalez carries the furniture he managed to save from his home in Catia La Mar, Venezuela, after it got blown up during the airstrikes. His aunt, Rosa Gonzalez, 80, who lived with him, died during the strike.

item.title: A Pardon and a Prosecution in New York Show Trump’s Personal Geopolitics
item.description: The facts in the cases of Nicolás Maduro and Juan Orlando Hernández are strikingly similar. The men’s fates are not.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich

media:content.media:credit: Jorge Cabrera/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: When President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras was extradited in 2022, his nation’s capital celebrated. President Trump pardoned him last month anyway.

item.title: What to Know About Canceled Flights in the Caribbean Amid U.S. Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The F.A.A. grounded U.S. flights in the region because of the Trump administration’s military action in Venezuela, stranding travelers and disrupting vacations.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root and Claire Fahy

media:content.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Travelers at Luis Muñoz Marin International Airport near San Juan, Puerto Rico, were among the potentially thousands of stranded travelers in the Caribbean.

item.title: In Toppling Maduro, Trump Risks Blowback from ‘America First’ Base
item.description: President Trump’s pledge that the United States would “run” Venezuela for an indefinite period showed he is willing to enter foreign conflicts he once promised to end.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump speaking about the attack on Venezuela from his private club and residence Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Long Wanted to ‘Take the Oil.’ He Says He’ll Do It in Venezuela.
item.description: The White House had pointed to drug trafficking and migration as reasons to crack down on Nicolás Maduro. But oil emerged as central to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Workers of the Venezuelan state oil company PDVSA in September. There was little immediate clarity on Saturday as to how the White House envisions the United States profiting from Venezuela’s oil.

item.title: ¿Quién es Delcy Rodríguez?
item.description: La líder interina es conocida por adherirse a ideales de izquierda, hacer frente a las sanciones de Estados Unidos y la Unión Europea, y tender puentes con la comunidad empresarial de Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: La vicepresidenta de Venezuela, Delcy Rodríguez, quien juró su cargo como líder interina del país el sábado, durante una entrevista en Caracas, Venezuela, en septiembre.

item.title: How Manhattan Federal Court Would Handle the Trial of a President
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s president, could stand trial in Federal District Court in New York City, the site of other high-profile court proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his wife, Cilia Flores, were flown to New York on Saturday to face an indictment charging them with cocaine trafficking and narco-terrorism crimes.

item.title: Base Pairs
item.description: This Sunday puzzle by Gene Louise De Vera breaks free from the laboratory.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Sergei Gapon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Lightning illuminated church spires in the Belarus town of Kreva in 2020.

item.title: On a Brooklyn Boulevard, Mamdani Revives a Project Hampered by Scandal
item.description: The bike-lane project, a source of corruption charges during the Adams administration, will be finished as planned in Greenpoint, Mayor Zohran Mamdani said.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said he would finish the original, full plan for the roadway as soon as weather permitted, and that he would not be “bowed by big-money interests.”

item.title: Who Is Cilia Flores, Maduro’s Wife, and Why Was She Captured Alongside Him?
item.description: Operating largely from the shadows, Ms. Flores, the first lady of Venezuela, helped consolidate Mr. Maduro’s rule while controlling the judiciary and amassing wealth through corruption, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his wife, Cilia Flores, during a rally in Caracas, Venezuela, in December. They were both captured and taken to the United States on Jan. 3.

item.title: How a New York Times Reporter Got a Phone Interview With Trump After Maduro’s Capture
item.description: How did a New York Times reporter reach the president right after he announced that the United States had captured Venezuela’s leader?
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump speaks at a news conference at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday.

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez desafía a Trump y llama a Maduro el ‘único presidente’ de Venezuela
item.description: El presidente Trump dijo que la nueva dirigente de Venezuela ayudaría a Estados Unidos a manejar el país. Pero ella ha denunciado la incursión.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Brittainy Newman para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, quien fue vicepresidenta de Venezuela bajo el mandato del presidente Nicolás Maduro, juró el cargo de presidenta interina el sábado, dijo EE. UU.

item.title: With the President Gone, Venezuelans Race to Stock Up on Food
item.description: People hit grocery stores on Saturday as they anxiously waited for word on what would happen next.
item.dc:creator: Sheyla Urdaneta and Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Residents wait in line at a supermarket in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday. Venezuelans crowded stores after the U.S. strikes in the country and the removal of its president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Así se desarrolló la ‘Operación Resolución Absoluta’ de EE. UU. para capturar a Maduro
item.description: El presidente Trump ofreció detalles de la planificación del operativo, incluida la construcción de una réplica de la casa de seguridad de Maduro, donde las fuerzas de operaciones especiales practicaron.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Luis Jaimes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Zohran Mamdani Called President Trump to Criticize Venezuela Strikes
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York accused President Trump of violating international law. It was the first time he had criticized the president since their White House meeting.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: During a news conference on Saturday, Mayor Zohran Mamdani said he had spoken to President Trump and criticized the capture of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela.

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s new leader, boasts leftist credentials
item.description: The interim leader is known for hewing to left-wing ideals, facing sanctions by the U.S. and European Union and building bridges with Venezuela’s business community.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vice President Delcy Rodríguez of Venezuela, who was sworn in as the country’s interim leader on Saturday, during an interview in Caracas, Venezuela, in September.

item.title: Before Nicolás Maduro, There Was Manuel Noriega
item.description: The Venezuelan leader is now in U.S. custody. Decades earlier, the United States deposed the strongman who led Panama.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Herve Merliac/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Gen. Manuel Noriega was the de facto ruler of Panama until his capture by U.S. forces in 1989.

item.title: Trump publica una imagen de Maduro esposado y con los ojos vendados
item.description: El presidente Trump compartió el sábado en las redes sociales una fotografía que, según dijo, mostraba a Nicolás Maduro a bordo de un buque de guerra estadounidense.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘This Is Purely a War of Choice’
item.description: About the U.S. attack on Venezuela, the columnist Jamelle Bouie says, “This is a plainly illegal war, a plainly illegal action, one that violates international law, one that is plainly unconstitutional, even anti-constitutional.”
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Defies Trump and Calls Maduro the ‘Only President’
item.description: President Trump said that Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, would help the United States run Venezuela. She quickly said the opposite.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, who was Venezuela’s vice president under President Nicolás Maduro, was sworn in as interim president on Saturday, the U.S. said.

item.title: Trump Shares Photo of Captured Nicolás Maduro, Blindfolded and Handcuffed
item.description: The Venezuelan president and his wife were flown out of Caracas by helicopter to the U.S.S. Iwo Jima, a warship taking them to New York.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Is It Legal for U.S. to ‘Run’ Venezuela After Maduro’s Capture? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The operation revives disputes over the legality of the 1989 Panama intervention, enhanced by President Trump’s vow to “run” Venezuela and Nicolás Maduro’s formal status as president.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Leonardo Fernandez Viloria/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Smoke rising from Fuerte Tiuna, a military complex in Caracas, on Saturday morning. U.S. troops captured President Nicolás Maduro in a raid of a safe house.

item.title: What We Know About the U.S. Operation in Venezuela and Maduro’s Capture
item.description: U.S. forces carried out an audacious raid on the country’s capital, seizing President Nicolás Maduro. President Trump said the United States now intends to “run” Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Luis Jaimes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Forces Will Run Venezuela After Capturing Maduro
item.description: President Trump signaled plans for U.S. military presence in Venezuela after U.S. forces struck the nation and captured President Nicolás Maduro. The U.S. closed its embassy in Venezuela in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters

item.title: What to Know About Venezuela’s Oil Industry as Trump Plans U.S. Intervention
item.description: Venezuela claims to have more than 300 billion barrels in the ground, but it is only producing about one million barrels a day.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Cronología de la tensión entre EE. UU. y Venezuela
item.description: El gobierno de Trump lleva meses aumentando la presión sobre el gobierno de Maduro mediante una serie de maniobras diplomáticas y militares.
item.dc:creator: Isabela Espadas Barros Leal and Genevieve Glatsky

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times

item.title: Trump dijo que EE. UU. va a ‘manejar’ Venezuela y Maduro llegó a Nueva York
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez, la vicepresidenta de Venezuela que juró como líder interina el sábado, contradijo al presidente Trump al rechazar la intervención estadounidense. Maduro y su esposa fueron trasladados a Nueva York para enfrentar cargos.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Matias Delacroix/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Pedestrians running after explosions were heard in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday.

item.title: Maduro Arrives in N.Y.; Trump Says U.S. Will ‘Run’ Venezuela
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, the ousted president of Venezuela, arrived in Brooklyn and will be held on drugs and weapons charges. The country’s interim leader demanded his return.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
